hints_html: Use the given second derivative and check the sign of the second derivative between points where the second derivative is zero and undefined.
hints_latex:
Use the given second derivative and check the sign of the second
derivative between points where the second derivative is zero and

hints_raw: Use the given second derivative and check the sign of the second derivative between points where the second derivative is zero and undefined.
question: 6 (c)
sols_html:
We are given that

\(\displaystyle f''(x) = -(12/25)x^{-7/5} + (42/25)x^{-12/5} = (1/25)x^{-12/5}(-12x + 42)\)

and this second derivative is undefined at \(x=0\). The second derivative is 0 when \(-12x + 42 = 0\), that is, when \(x = 42/12 = 7/2\). So we check the intervals \(\displaystyle (-\infty,0),(0,7/2),(7/2,\infty)\) individually.

Note that \(x^{-12/5} = \frac1{x^{12/5}} = \frac1{\sqrt[5]{x^{12}}} > 0\) for all values of \(x \not= 0\).

Case 1

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (-\infty,0)\end{aligned}\]

We test that the second derivative at a point in the interval, say \(x = -1\), which gives a value of \(54/25 > 0\). Thus the function is concave up on this interval.

Case 2

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (0,7/2)\end{aligned}\]

We test that the derivative at a point in the interval, say \(x = 1\), which gives a value of \(30/25 > 0\). Thus the function is concave up on this interval.

Case 3

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (7/2,\infty)\end{aligned}\]

We test that the derivative at a point in the interval, say \(x = 10\), which gives a value of \((1/25) * 10^{-12/5} * (-78) < 0\). Thus the function is concave down on this interval.

This completes the question.

is 0 when $-12x + 42 = 0$, that is, when $x = 42/12 = 7/2$. So we check

individually.

Note that $x^{-12/5} = \frac1{x^{12/5}} = \frac1{\sqrt[5]{x^{12}}} > 0$
for all values of $x \not= 0$.

Case 1\begin{align*}
\displaystyle (-\infty,0)

We test that the second derivative at a point in the interval, say

Case 2\begin{align*}
\displaystyle (0,7/2)

\end{align*}

We test that the derivative at a point in the interval, say $x = 10$,
which gives a value of $(1/25) * 10^{-12/5} * (-78) < 0$. Thus the
function is concave down on this interval.

This completes the question.
sols_raw:
We are given that

<math>
\displaystyle f''(x) = -(12/25)x^{-7/5} + (42/25)x^{-12/5} = (1/25)x^{-12/5}(-12x + 42)
</math>

and this second derivative is undefined at <math> x=0 </math>. The second derivative is 0 when <math> -12x + 42 = 0 </math>, that is, when <math>x = 42/12 = 7/2 </math>. So we check the intervals <math> \displaystyle (-\infty,0),(0,7/2),(7/2,\infty) </math> individually.

Note that <math> x^{-12/5} = \frac1{x^{12/5}} = \frac1{\sqrt[5]{x^{12}}} > 0</math> for all values of <math> x \not= 0</math>.

Case 1: <math> \displaystyle (-\infty,0) </math>

We test that the second derivative at a point in the interval, say <math> x = -1 </math>, which gives a value of <math> 54/25 > 0 </math>. Thus the function is concave up on this interval.

Case 2: <math> \displaystyle (0,7/2) </math>

We test that the derivative at a point in the interval, say <math> x = 1 </math>, which gives a value of <math>  30/25 > 0 </math>.  Thus the function is concave up on this interval.

Case 3: <math> \displaystyle (7/2,\infty) </math>

We test that the derivative at a point in the interval, say <math> x = 10 </math>, which gives a value of <math> (1/25) * 10^{-12/5} * (-78) < 0 </math>. Thus the function is concave down on this interval.

This completes the question.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 5-11, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions.

6. Let \(f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}\). Note that the domain of \(f\) is the set of all nonzero real numbers; for example, \(f(-1) = -2 + 3 = 1\).

(c) Determine the interval(s) where f(x) is concave up and concave down, respectively. You may use:

\(\displaystyle f''(x) = -(12/25)x^{-7/5} + (42/25)x^{-12/5} = (1/25)x^{-12/5}(-12x + 42).\)
